problem: The saw was running but getting extremely hot in both brush holders, with visible smoke and burning smell. Both brushes were getting scalding hot at around 70-80°C, indicating the armature was burnt out.
failure_reason: Repair was not completed as the armature needed to be ordered and was not in stock, but repair was deemed worthwhile and will be completed later

problem: The hammer drill had power but was not running. The brushes were worn but not badly enough to stop the machine, indicating another electrical issue was preventing operation.
The saw was making a horrible burning sound when stopping, initially suspected to be bearing problems but turned out to be a loose blade causing slippage during braking.
The impact wrench motor was spinning but the anvil wasn't turning due to cold welding between the steel components, causing the mechanism to bind up completely.
Customer reported the motor was burnt out, smoking heavily, and wouldn't cut straight. The actual issue was the blade was installed backwards, causing it to burn the wood instead of cutting.
The cordless miter saw was running and working properly but was stuck at one angle and couldn't be adjusted because the angle adjustment lever was broken.
A nearly new 2024 hammer drill wasn't running at all. The brushes were completely jammed due to being caked with mud, sand, cement dust, and corrosion, with water still present inside the housing.

The forward and reverse change lever was broken - could go forward but couldn't get it on reverse unless you poke it with your finger. One of the little ends on the change lever had snapped off, likely from getting a bang, being put down wrong, falling over, or having something drop on it.

The speed selector switch board was faulty - the light was working but it wasn't letting you select any other speed. The tool was stuck on high speed and couldn't change down through the speeds. The problem was caused by dust getting into the switch mechanism which acts like little bellows, sucking in dust every time the button is pressed and released.
Machine was making noise and had issues running, plus the power cord was kinked and improperly installed near where a screw could go through the cable
18 volt impact wrench was making bad noise and had a seized bearing that caused the motor to keep spinning, rubbing against the housing and melting the plastic clamshell cover
Machine was making noise indicating brush issues and had a broken/unlit power cord tip
Tool holder was not holding bits properly due to worn out keyways, plus had perished rubber rings, broken cap, and debris inside requiring complete disassembly and cleaning
Machine had electrical problems and the armature was blown out with visible damage and raised spots causing it to eat away at the brushes
failure_reason: Repair cost of approximately €400 for motor replacement not economical compared to €600 for new equivalent machine

problem: Customer reported the grinder went 'bang' but no actual fault could be identified during testing - machine ran normally
Switch mechanism was dirty and cruded up, affecting operation
Switch mechanism was dirty with grease and dirt buildup around the switch area
Something was binding up inside the tool, steel bush had moved out of position and was not flush
Switch mechanism was dirty and needed cleaning
Spring in tool holder was not holding properly, spring was completely gone and steel ball was not being held in position
Switch mechanism was dirty and cruded up, described as badly cruded
Double charger with one side working and one side completely dead. Shows signs of water damage with rust marks on the board.
failure_reason: Water damage caused one power supply board to fail, replacement boards not available separately

problem: Chuck completely rusted solid and would not open, motor field/stator burnt out with copper windings turned black from normal color, tool had been left in rain causing total rust seizure.
Tool covered in thick black paint that prevented switch from operating properly.
Water damage caused motor windings to turn black, fan melted onto brush holder, motor completely burnt out from overheating.
failure_reason: Motor completely burnt out, not cost effective to repair given low tool price

problem: Trigger not going through speeds properly, switch connector melted and burnt wires due to overload.
Gearbox not dropping into gear properly due to dirt buildup preventing selector from engaging fully, chuck seized from water damage.
No clear problem identified, appeared to be working normally when tested.
Wiring completely melted due to excessive current draw, connectors totally melted through from overuse and overloading the motor.
failure_reason: Too risky to repair due to potential battery damage from short circuit

problem: Motor windings burnt and turned wrong color, brush contacts cooked from excessive heat and overuse.
failure_reason: Motor windings burnt beyond repair, would fail again quickly due to abuse

problem: Power cord damaged, blades completely broken and smashed, depth adjustment jammed with rust, tool clogged with sawdust preventing motor ventilation.
component: power cord, blades, and depth adjustment

problem: Tool holder shattered and fell apart, common fault for fire department use where tools get regularly abused taking cars apart
Gun was jammed and not firing properly, nail stuck in the mechanism
Motor burnt out, not starting, stinking burning smell from motor, very hot
Charger not working, no power output
failure_reason: Not worth repairing due to cost and complexity of diagnosing board-level faults

problem: High pitched whining sound, switch working but no power getting through, motor not running
failure_reason: All components integrated into one piece, replacement cost equals price of new machine

problem: Brushes completely worn out, motor not running properly
Forward/reverse switch broken and buried on both sides, speed selector connector gone, switch problems
failure_reason: Switch assembly too damaged from apparent physical trauma, multiple components failed

problem: Motor brushes completely worn out, burnt through to wire, spring coils damaged
Dead, not starting, plastic housing melted from excessive heat, aluminum housing discolored from heat
failure_reason: Excessive heat damage melted plastic housing and damaged internal components beyond repair

problem: Batteries green with corrosion, contacts corroded, battery acid leaked out destroying cells
failure_reason: Severe corrosion and acid leakage destroyed battery cells beyond repair

problem: Magnesium base broken, guard housing broken off from being dropped
Motor brushes were worn out with nothing left on one brush, causing performance issues
Motor not starting in bump mode but would start on plunge, trigger dirty inside with blocked contacts not always engaging the motor
Burnt and melted brush holders from heavy use and high amp draw over long periods
Tool not rotating - engaging and working but just not spinning, clutch gear had a single broken tooth
Down on power, starts to smoke after running a little while, motor field burnt up and generating too much heat with worn brushes
Motor burnt out, lost magnetism in field due to overheating
failure_reason: Motor completely burnt out and switch also failed, not economical to repair

problem: Switch problem and motor issues
failure_reason: Both motor and switch failed, not economical to repair

problem: Gearbox issue not going fully into speed, trigger problem
failure_reason: Multiple issues including gearbox and trigger, not economical to repair

problem: Motor burnt out and switch failed
Chuck mechanism stuck, chisel getting stuck in the tool holder due to rust and lack of lubrication
The lead cable was cut and damaged with live wire exposed, and the motor was running but the chuck was not turning due to being not properly in gear
Brushed motor would not run initially, motor brushes were overheated, cracked, and stuck in holders causing poor contact
Chuck was getting hot and failing, trigger was starting to fail
Armature was burnt with raised segments and big gaps, gears were also gone, machine sounded extremely gritty with a lot of slop
failure_reason: Repair not economically viable - armature cost €45 while complete grinder can be bought for €60

problem: Power cord had 10-11 cuts and exposed wires, motor brushes were worn, bearing screws had come loose causing noise and movement
No apparent problem found during testing - tool was running and functioning properly
Tool would not run initially, then started running intermittently due to worn motor brushes that were sticking
Gearbox was worn out, anvil had excessive slack, switch was failing
failure_reason: Multiple expensive components needed replacement making repair uneconomical

problem: Tool holder/chuck was not holding bits properly due to failed lifter spring, switch needed cleaning
Bearing had failed causing the tool to barely turn and bind up, with bearing components scattered inside the housing
Machine was making noise and not running properly, with a kinked power cord that was never installed correctly
18 volt 3/4 inch impact wrench was making bad noise and had seized bearing causing motor to rub against housing and melt the plastic
Machine was popping and making noise, plus had a broken power cord with bare wires at the tip
SDS drill was not holding bits properly because the keyways in the tool holder were completely worn out, plus had perished rubber rings and debris inside
Magnetic drill had electrical problems with blown armature that was raised up and eating away the brushes
failure_reason: Repair cost of approximately 400 euros for motor replacement was not economical compared to buying a new equivalent machine for 600 euros

problem: Customer reported the 9 inch grinder went bang, but no fault could be identified during testing
Off square and not cutting straight. The blade was sitting too far back and the base had dropped, causing cuts to be out of square by 2-3 millimeters.
Chuck was stuck and jammed in the down position. The rubber cap was worn through from drilling too close to concrete walls, causing the chuck to stay locked in open position.
Tool was not working due to internal wire fatigue and breakage from constant vibration. Wire broke at the motor pin connection point.
failure_reason: Wire broke at the motor pin with nothing left to reconnect to. Motor replacement would cost 70-80 euro, not worth it for a tool that costs about 150 euro new.

problem: Not cutting straight, blade dropping to one side. Tool holder was very stiff and difficult to engage properly.
failure_reason: Tool holder is part of lifting rod and gearbox assembly costing 120-130 euro to replace, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Intermittent operation - sometimes working, sometimes stopping dead. Switch was not making full contact consistently.
failure_reason: Switch costs 50 euro but the machine can be bought new for about 90 euro online, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Completely dead, no LED light coming on, no response when trigger pulled. Brushless machine with suspected controller failure.
failure_reason: Controller replacement would cost as much as buying a new machine, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Not working despite LED light coming on. Switch had blown MOSFET, brushes were worn, and stator/field was weak causing high current draw.
failure_reason: Multiple issues requiring switch (60 euro) and brushes (7 euro), plus weak motor field likely to cause future failures. Tool heavily used and worn, better to replace.

problem: Trigger switch was jammed all the way in and not functioning properly. Switch had come out of its track/groove, possibly from being knocked or twisted.
Tool was completely dead - would not turn on at all, no LED light working, despite brushes being brand new and all connections appearing good
failure_reason: Repair pending - controller needs to be ordered and replaced

problem: Tool keeps running but eventually stops and won't work again for a long time, maybe a couple days later it might run again
failure_reason: Not cost effective to repair - motor unit replacement would cost 90-100 Euro but tool can be bought for 100-140 Euro

problem: Grinder was running very freely, motor sputtering, and not stopping quickly due to worn brushes with very little material left
Jigsaw was completely jammed and wouldn't move at all due to gearbox being packed solid with sawdust over time
Drill bit was broken and stuck inside the tool holder chuck, couldn't be removed normally
Nail gun was not firing properly and not sinking nails correctly due to loss of nitrogen gas pressure in the system
Tool holder was worn out - bits would go in but just spin inside the holder, and handle was also spinning freely due to broken indexing disc and worn keyways
Trigger was jammed in position and wouldn't move, drill wouldn't operate due to trigger mechanism being stuck with dirt and grit
Drill bit was stuck in the chuck and the chuck mechanism wasn't working, chuck was jammed on so tight it couldn't be removed normally
One of the screws in the nail guide had broken off, and during service found the reed valve assembly was loose and nail guide was cracked
Making a whirring sound during operation, bearing starting to go dry and fail
Makes noise but not hammering correctly, something wrong with the piston inside, change lever was damaged from previous forced repair attempt
Switch burnt out with melted wires, not working
Making buzzing noise and going very slow, high pitch squeal, controller failing intermittently
failure_reason: Controller failure not worth fixing - costs nearly same as new machine

problem: Works intermittently, sometimes runs and sometimes doesn't work at all
failure_reason: Electronic problem not worth fixing - motor assembly costs around €300 on a €600 machine

problem: Not working, controller/switch failure, machine has done virtually no work but stopped functioning
failure_reason: Controller assembly costs at least €100 on a €200 machine - too expensive to repair

problem: Mechanical problem with blade holder mechanism, pin had come out causing noise and rattling
Noise from gearbox, bearing failure causing rattling, wrong bearing size fitted from factory
Noisy operation, bearing failure and brush holder corrosion, rubber overmolding deteriorating
The grinder turns on but is not doing anything. Investigation revealed one of the field coils had failed internally with a broken connection.
The anvil broke and there was rough play and noise in the gearbox housing, indicating wear.
The drill is hammering but slipping on drill mode due to a broken or disengaged clutch ring.
failure_reason: Parts need to be ordered - clutch kit not in stock

problem: Chuck is not functioning properly and there is an oil leak. Tool needs a new chuck, sleeve, and cap.
failure_reason: Parts need to be ordered - chuck not in stock

problem: Making grinding or bearing noise during operation. Investigation revealed a failed bearing with the cage broken and balls coming out.
Battery retainers are burnt up and bent, motor is completely worn out and seized, controller has failed, and LED light stopped working.
failure_reason: Too many expensive parts need replacement - motor and controller both failed, not economically viable to repair

problem: Motor is rubbing and not running 100% smooth due to worn bearing and armature rubbing against the field due to worn plastic housing.
Trigger not working - motor runs in bump mode but won't fire in single shot mode due to dust blocking the trigger switch contacts.
The blade holder came off when the pin holding it to the spindle snapped, completely detaching the blade holding mechanism.
Tool not switching on, no power. Also had a stiff tool holder that was jammed with grit and stones, preventing full travel to release the chisel.
Makes clicking sounds, motor turns freely but won't run properly. Likely controller, switch, or Hall effect sensor failure.
failure_reason: Motor unit costs over £220 and the complete tool can be bought new for €270, making repair uneconomical

problem: Radio would not power on with either battery or mains power. Power cord was broken with live and neutral wires separated.
Motor runs but spindle/anvil not turning. Steel balls in the hammer mechanism were jammed due to debris and grit in the tracks, and one steel ball was cracked/damaged.
SDS Plus tool holder keyways completely worn away, allowing bits to move around inside and fall out. Power cord also needed replacement. Missing steel balls from tool holder mechanism.
No power, motor would not run. One wire was broken at the connection point.
Compressor would not power on. Switch contacts were stuck together due to dust and dirt accumulation, preventing proper operation.
The tool holder is damaged and locked in the open position. Blade will go in but it's not staying because the spring mechanism that should lock the blade in place has failed.
The switch has failed completely - no click when pressed and the saw won't turn on. Also has damaged wiring with live cable showing.
23 gauge headless pinner no longer sinking nails flush - nails are firing but sticking proud of the timber. The firing pin has actually broken, not just worn.
Bearing has completely failed and the field has come loose, causing rubbing. Machine sounds very bad and steel balls from bearing are floating around inside.
Old half-inch electric drill is tripping the breaker when switched on due to internal wiring shorting to the metal body. After testing, discovered the armature is shorted out.
failure_reason: Armature is shorted out and no replacement parts are available for this old machine

problem: 50L dust extractor not working at all - no power and indicator light not coming on when switched on.
Saw not running properly, brush holder melted, brushes are burnt and of very poor quality construction.
Tool was running rough with a squealing sound at the end, something was squeaking when turning. Fan had shifted and was rubbing against the housing causing noise and potential overheating.
Tool was completely dead, not responding at all, no LED light coming on when battery inserted. Controller appeared to be faulty.
failure_reason: Repair not economically viable - controller costs 90-100 euros but complete tool only costs 150-160 euros to buy new

problem: Motor was making grinding noise indicating bearing failure. Field winding tip was broken with windings pulled out and catching on armature. Tackle ring on armature was coming loose.
Motor runs but not driving screws properly. Screws were sitting loose and not being driven in.
Motor making bad sounds, armature had a blown segment that was completely missing. Tool wouldn't start when stopped on the dead segment but would start when blade was moved to next segment.
Motor sounding rough with grinding noise from bearings. Multiple bearings were worn out and making noise during operation.
Tool had no plug and very short, hardened power cord that was impractical to use
Tool was not running, brushes had been removed and there was a smooth spot on the armature where the brushes had rubbed against the commutator
Tool had vibration and grinding noise from bearings, plus very short power cord
Tool had burnt out armature with darker segments that were blown
failure_reason: Armature replacement would cost more than buying a new grinder, making repair economically unviable

problem: Tool was totally burnt out with blown segments, raised segments acting like a file, burnt windings coming out, and broken spicer bars
failure_reason: Armature was completely destroyed and replacement would cost more than a new grinder

problem: Tool had squealing noise, messed up wiring from previous lead change, burnt brushes, bad armature, failing bearings, and blown field
failure_reason: Multiple major components failed including field, armature, bearings, and brushes making repair too expensive to be worthwhile

problem: Fake Makita SDS hammer drill with counterfeit badges was not switching on at all, doing nothing. Power cord was broken internally.
Customer said it only needed a belt, but upon inspection the drive belt was snapped in half and multiple bearings were completely collapsed and rough, causing the belt failure.

Trimmer was not starting at all, not even a kick. Switch was positioned incorrectly and cocked to one side. Motor head was clogged with grass clippings blocking air vents causing overheating. Shaft connection was loose and pins were missing.
component: trigger switch, air filter, and shaft connection pins

problem: 2006 router was making noise like a jet engine taking off due to worn bearings causing excessive noise and vibration.
Collet cone was completely jammed in the spindle and could not be removed. The cone had worn and rounded over, preventing any bits from being inserted. Customer could not use the tool at all.
No cable, switch was gone, there was something going on with the brushes with a big gap, and one brush was broken with a sharp break
Not working, making a clicking sound which is normally a sign that the brushes have popped out due to wear
Cable had live and neutral wires twisted together in a poor repair job, lead was broken with no neutral connection, brushes were worn but not too bad
Gear problems - gears were chewed up and stripped out, both the gears in the head and the gear on the armature were completely stripped
Gears were stripped out, brushes were completely gone with not much left of them and about to pop, one bearing was starting to fail and becoming very slack
Machine was not running at all despite being switched on and having power to the socket
Machine stopped working completely, was a 20 year old machine from 2004 with original molded plug
Machine was running and hammering but had a service light on indicating brushes were worn out, plus bearing was getting slack
Machine was making a nasty grinding sound and running roughly, turned out to be a counterfeit Bosch with broken connecting rod inside the hammer mechanism mixed with plastic debris in the grease
Machine was running way too fast with no variable speed control and red light was on, hammer action would only work when slowing down but stopped when at full speed
Machine was not getting any power, discovered a broken wire that someone had tried to glue back together
The tool doesn't have the same power as it used to and there's a burning smell coming from it.
The grinder is noisy and stuff, making grinding/grinding noises due to a failed bearing.
Battery only showing 4.4-4.5 volts which is way too low for an 18V battery that should show between 17-20 volts. Individual cell banks were showing 0.92-0.94 volts which is well below viable voltage.
Battery had a fall and looks damaged, the casing looks damaged, there's dirt inside, and having trouble getting it to connect to the top because even the pins are damaged.

Not even lighting LED in the tool, won't charge, makes clicking sounds on charger but doesn't actually charge, showing just over 9 volts and dropping. Individual cell banks showing very low voltage around 1.71-1.75 volts.

No bars on charge, not registering on drill, not even lighting LED, showing 12.7-13.74 volts which is far too low. Corrosion present and complete disconnection where nickel strip spot weld had given way, causing one cell to carry full load while other did nothing.
Tool had two issues - switch problem causing performance issues and chuck/bit holder not retaining bits properly
Owner had to put a screw in to hold the switch on which was not ergonomic and uncomfortable on the finger
Chuck was missing/not working properly and there was hesitation in the trigger response due to dust buildup inside the tool
Bit holder broke off inside the collet, preventing new bits from being inserted properly
Tool was making a horrendous screeching noise during operation
The lights were on but the tool wasn't working - completely non-functional due to worn out motor brushes
The nailer had intermittent operation - sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't. The tool had been previously opened and had a switch cleaning done before.
The hammer drill was not working at all. Motor was burnt with heat damage to the brushes and armature, and the hammer mechanism needed servicing.
The drill would sometimes go forward when trying to switch to reverse mode instead of reversing direction as intended. The directional control was unreliable.
Performance issues, motor brushes were well worn down and away from the top, burnt or broken terminals, one brush broke during removal
Tool was very greasy from being used in a car repair workshop and had some operational issues
Faulty trigger - the saw was trying to work but could not manage to operate properly
Quick release mechanism lever was not pushing back far enough for blades to fit in properly due to worn blade clamp
Battery was dead with no battery indicator working, one bank of cells was significantly lower voltage at 3.73V compared to others around 4V
The tool was dropping the battery pack - sometimes it would catch if you wiggled it but the connection was unreliable and the battery would fall out during use.
The tool was running continuously and the light was staying on after releasing the trigger. The switch was not disengaging properly, causing the motor to keep running.
The saw was producing smoke when the trigger was pulled and had significant dust buildup. The blade holder mechanism was jammed and difficult to operate, requiring extensive cleaning and lubrication.
Dust coming out of the grinder, overheating issues that melted the brush housing and stopped the brushes from working properly. The brush ring was melted and couldn't be removed easily.
The drill was completely dead with no power when plugged in. There was a slight gap between the armature and brush indicating the brushes were worn out and not making proper contact.
The impact wrench was not working and needed investigation. It was stripped down, cleaned, and reassembled.
The laser was not turning on despite having good battery voltage. The issue was traced to corroded battery contacts and springs in the battery compartment.
The chuck doesn't tighten very well and needs replacement
The drill was not working at all, no response when trigger pulled. Motor brushes were stuck in position and crumbling, with signs of heat damage and melting in the motor

Another drill from an auction that was not working. Motor brushes were not sliding properly, one side was crumbling and stuck. Had to improvise by butchering brushes from the previous repair to make a working set
The yellow battery indicator component was broken on the Makita battery, preventing the battery indicator from functioning properly
The impact driver was not firing or ramping up properly despite having a full battery installed
failure_reason: Did not have the replacement springs needed to complete the repair - springs were broken and would need to be ordered

problem: Very dirty with putrid power cord, drill chuck has rust, handle has a crack on one side, machine not working at all, filter capacitor component ruptured and exploded, metal shards in gearbox from broken thread
Does not work when plugged in and turned on, very dirty, switch was bypassed by previous owner in failed repair attempt, motor brushes corroded and stuck in their sockets unable to slide down
Damaged power cord, some scratches and dirt on the outside
Damaged power cord, very dirty, clutch was previously repaired with brass screw insertion
The power cord needs to be replaced, damaged filter component, motor brushes are quite worn off and the commutator is pretty dirty with both corrosion and carbon dust covering the surface
component: power cord, filter component, motor brushes, commutator

problem: Very dirty with several signs of wear, cable relief is broken, orange power cord is damaged at one end
Battery was completely dead with only 0.022 volts and would not charge on the charger, showing just a red light
Tool was getting flashing lights and not working properly due to dirty battery contacts with black buildup preventing good electrical contact
Tool would not turn on when dial was turned, had black dust everywhere around the tool indicating internal motor problems, and had a major crack/break in the housing case
failure_reason: Major structural damage to housing with full break, plus internal motor issues creating black dust - not economically repairable

problem: Router had a major broken piece in the housing - part of the entire housing/base was broken off
failure_reason: Required replacement part is obsolete and no longer available from manufacturer, and replacement cost would exceed tool value

problem: Spindle lock would not engage in any position, and the shaft was spinning freely without being secured due to missing woodruff key
failure_reason: Could not find the correct size woodruff key at hardware store and manufacturer doesn't sell replacement parts - would need to custom grind one

problem: Battery showed 10 volts but would not charge, had corrosion on the circuit board that was preventing proper charging function
Motor appeared to be completely locked up and would not turn at all when powered on
failure_reason: Multiple internal failures including broken gear tooth, missing snap ring, broken motor fan blade - repair cost would exceed tool value

problem: Battery showed zero volts initially, after jump starting showed 19 volts but still gave four blinking lights error and would not charge due to unbalanced cells
failure_reason: One cell significantly lower voltage than others causing controller to prevent charging/use, would require spot welding replacement cell

problem: Large battery pack would not charge and had two faulty cells reading lower voltage than the other cells in the pack
failure_reason: Two 18650 cells were faulty and would need replacement via spot welding, not confident in repair skills for safe resale

problem: Tool was pretty dirty with grease buildup and dirt accumulation from typical use, requiring deep cleaning of internal components and case
Tool had paint or plaster covering the outside and needed thorough cleaning of external surfaces and some internal cleaning
The drill was repaired in a previous video and is now being used in the current project, indicating it had some prior malfunction that was fixed.

Power cord had been cut and a screw from the gearbox was missing, indicating someone had previously opened it. The grease in the gearbox was very dry and sticky, and there was some surface rust on the armature.
Green Bosch angle grinder had a ton of rust inside the enclosure from being at the scrapyard for weeks, and the plastic button and connected parts were broken into several pieces.
component: internal electronics and plastic button mechanism
failure_reason: Extensive rust damage throughout the internal components and broken plastic parts made it unsalvageable

problem: The drill needed a new chuck replacement
Tool needed a front rubber replacement because it was working very well but the rubber component needed replacement
failure_reason: The rubber did not fit properly relative to the part number and appeared to be the wrong size or type

problem: Old power cord that had clearly seen better days needed replacement
Hammer drill rated for 115 volts AC but needed to work in Germany with 230 volt power supply, may have been damaged from being plugged into wrong voltage outlet
The air compressor was running well but had one issue - it was very loud

Multiple issues: old rubber o-rings had dry rot, old gas hoses were brittle with wear and tear, old feet of welding cart not suited for modern gas cylinders, oxygen valve in handpiece had a clear leak, acetylene was passing through oxygen valve to the outside
Radio selector knob was malfunctioning - would jump in steps of two, do nothing, or sometimes go backwards making it almost impossible to select the right track
Motor from treadmill had one of the brush springs that had come loose, broken fan, and various external components that needed removal

The plastic parts holding the motor brushes have melted and are stuck to the enclosure. There appears to have been a fire. The turns in the armature have melted and are completely destroyed. One of the little doors giving access to the motor brushes is broken.
failure_reason: The armature turns were completely melted and destroyed, making the repair beyond reasonable repair

problem: The bench grinder would only hum when switched on and would not start up. The motor was not spinning despite being powered on. Investigation revealed the centrifugal switch was broken and not functioning properly to disconnect the start capacitor after motor startup.
Broken cable guard on a professional firefighter submersible pump. Water had leaked into the outer compartment, likely due to screws not being perfectly watertight. The rotor looked a little rusty.
Wrench was rusty and dirty from being found in scrap yard trash
Tool was rusty and dirty from being found in scrap yard, required rust removal
Assembly was dusty and dirty with white dirt or dry rot collected around the belts, belts needed cleaning
Used for wire wheeling rust and grease removal - mentioned as a large grinder that he normally uses but switched to a smaller one for this task

Old flat belt was damaged, feed lever could only be moved with considerable effort, quill was almost stuck due to dried up old grease and dirt, column was very rusty, table and table lock lever were locked in place, power cord was severely damaged and needed replacement, old plastic knob on rotary switch was missing, paint job was in pitiful state
component: belt, feed mechanism, quill, power cord, switch knob, paint

problem: Power cord had been cut off, needed to check if water had leaked into the electronics
Missing plastic cover that it probably once had
Ancient drill with nasty old grease in reduction gear and incredibly resistant grime on the outside, broken wire on brush holder, rusty chuck, needed new power cord
component: reduction gear, brush holder wire, chuck, power cord

problem: Motor was spinning too slow, making unhealthy noises, and enclosure was heating up quickly due to severely overheated rotor winding that was damaged beyond reasonable repair
Steel wool was sucked through the air intake, shorting out parts of the commutator and causing damage to the plastic ring between commutator and rear ball bearing as well as the armature winding
Armature winding was damaged
failure_reason: No replacement armature available among salvaged parts

problem: Reduction gear made funny noises and showed considerable wear on the gears inside the gearbox

Little plastic nuts or caps that held the motor brushes in their holders had cracked, causing mains voltage to be present at brass holders on the outside of the enclosure without insulation. Also had very old paper capacitors from 1947 that needed replacement
Unit needed inspection and maintenance, required new power cord
One brush was missing entirely, the other brush was worn and damaged, and the armature winding was damaged

Old grinder with extremely rusty components, old three-phase power plug from before 1975, broken bakelite switch that was fixed with a screw, dirty old grease in bearings, rusty flanges and nuts that were difficult to remove, and no proper grinding wheel that fit the shaft diameter
Machine was not working properly, likely due to dirty and stuck motor brushes that couldn't move properly in their holders, causing intermittent operation, starting and stopping, or low power
Machine was sent in for general checkover before use, no specific problems identified during inspection
Machine was sent in for general checkover before use, no specific problems identified during inspection
Machine was making a slight rubbing sound, possibly due to rust from the spindle or internal dust buildup
Machine was sent in for general checkover before use, no specific problems identified during inspection
Machine sounded stiff and rough during operation, likely due to worn bearings causing it to not be properly centered, and had one stuck motor brush
Machine was making rough grinding sounds due to worn out crown and bevel gears in the gearbox, and had dirty motor brushes
Machine had a broken power cord near the plug and rough operation due to worn bearings, worn motor brushes, and a loose cooling fan
Very old machine that would not switch off properly and was making rough operational sounds, likely due to worn bearings and switch issues
The entire grinder was severely physically damaged - crushed by a vehicle (lorry or car). The housing was squashed, plug completely flattened, case torn up, and internal components damaged.
failure_reason: The armature was bent and the field was knocked, making it not worth fixing due to the extensive damage and high cost of replacement parts

problem: The chuck won't go on or won't stay on. The metal tool holder was visible poking through the worn rubber cap, and the sleeve was pushed all the way back.
The router had bad bearings making noise during operation. The machine was nearly 20 years old and the bearings needed replacement.
A drill bit was stuck in the chuck and the chuck would not open. The chuck had jammed up completely.
The grinder had a burnt brass spring connection between the field and brush holder. The connection had failed due to heavy use.

Complete failure with clicking sound indicating armature problems. The top bearing had collapsed and failed, causing metal debris in the gearbox, gear damage, armature rubbing against field, and eventual burnout.
failure_reason: Under warranty so will be replaced rather than repaired, but failure was caused by cascading damage from failed bearing

problem: The plastic slider switch on top had broken off, preventing the grinder from being turned on or off.

Motor problem - the motor was cooked/burned out. When plugged in and switched on, it showed clear signs of motor failure. The armature was blown with segments all raised up, cooked areas, and blown out sections. The brush holder was also melted and burnt.

The grinder motor was running but not cutting anything. The motor unit was not connected to the gear mechanism that drives the disc. The nut on top of the spindle had backed off, causing the gear to spin free without connecting to the motor armature.
Tool was not working and needed repair. It's described as being used heavily in a tire center where tools are subjected to extreme use.

The saw was not going initially, then started working but not running properly. The tool was covered in white dust (described as looking like it had been in 'Scarface's lab') and the variable speed switch was caked with dust and not being used. One brush was completely gone with nothing left.
The grinder was making sparks and not working properly. One brush had completely worn away and was stuck inside the motor housing in pieces.
The drill had a stuck chuck mechanism that wouldn't move up or down. The mechanism was seized and required disassembly to replace the O-ring and apply grease to the internal components.
Brushless drill was completely dead - not even putting on the light when battery was inserted
Bit holder was not staying in and dropping bits, which could be frustrating for the user
Nailer was not firing nails - described as having a broken pin
Tool was making noise and the catch ring was away, causing loud knocking sounds. The hammer was seized and wouldn't move properly, with broken O-ring and very dry internals
The circular saw was not working at all. Initial inspection ruled out worn motor brushes as the cause.
The chuck is not holding drill bits in place, there's no click when inserting bits, and it's not tightening properly to secure bits. The locking mechanism is loose and losing its position.
The saw was not working and suspected to have brush issues. Upon inspection, the brush holders were found to be melted and the brushes were worn down with very little left.

Tool goes sometimes and doesn't go other times. Motor was found to be burnt with evidence of heat damage and melting. After replacing motor and cleaning switch, the tool was losing power and not working properly.
failure_reason: Switch failure after motor replacement - tool still would not operate properly even with new motor and cleaned switch

problem: Tool was running rough, not sounding good, and was messing with the trigger response.
Sometimes it goes, sometimes it doesn't work. No power was getting from the battery through the control board to where it needed to go.
failure_reason: Circuit board failure - power was not passing through the electronic control module to operate the motor

problem: Battery would not charge or power tools. Had 18.6 volts but no power output. All cells were balanced at around 3.8 volts each.
Tool had no power at all - completely dead with no response when plugged in and switched on
Tool was not working at all - no response when battery was inserted and trigger pulled
failure_reason: Motor was burnt out with excessive heat damage. One brush was stuck and wouldn't move up or down, brush wire broke off, and there was too much heat damage to the motor to repair effectively

problem: Tool was problematic and very dirty with poor performance. Brushes were worn out and the entire tool was extremely dirty from use in a dairy farm environment
Issues with the trigger and maybe a bearing problem, plus the chuck will not slacken/loosen
Broke a bit off in the chuck and someone attempted to use adhesive (CT1 or Tech 7) to stick another bit in to use it
The sander was making noise but not sanding - no movement of the sanding pad despite having full battery power. Variable speed adjustment had no effect.
failure_reason: Motor had obvious burn damage and bearing issues. Despite cleaning, oiling bearings, and reassembly, the motor would not function properly due to internal damage.

problem: The SDS drill was cutting out intermittently during drilling operations. The battery terminals were severely damaged with visible holes burned through them, causing connection issues.
The drill was making noise like a bag of bottles and not functioning properly due to collapsed bearings in the motor assembly.
The magazine broke off the stapler. The owner mentioned he drove over it twice, which caused the magazine to break and separate from the main body of the tool.
The grinder was jammed and would not operate. It had been used professionally for farm fence work six days a week and had a rough life. There was rubbing and debris inside the motor housing.
failure_reason: Motor coil failure - the grinder was beyond repair with multiple coil issues and internal damage from heavy professional use

problem: The battery pack was showing 51% charge and 17.4 volts but would not charge properly. Upon opening, multiple cells were found to be defective.
failure_reason: Multiple bad cells (at least 3 identified as defective) - not worth repairing due to poor quality construction

problem: The grinder was not working at all - completely dead with no response when powered on
failure_reason: Suspected broken wires inside the switch controller assembly that could not be repaired

problem: The drill chuck was stuck and could not be removed, preventing normal operation. Chuck retention issues where sometimes it holds bits and sometimes it doesn't
The impact driver switch felt loose and faulty, and the tool had bit retention problems where sometimes it holds bits and sometimes it doesn't

Battery would not charge, showing only 2.9-3 volts which is below chargeable voltage for a 20 volt battery pack. Individual cell banks showed varying voltages from 0.39 to 0.79 volts, indicating severely discharged and unbalanced cells.
Battery would not charge, showing 10 volts total with individual cell banks reading between 2.34-2.92 volts. One bank was significantly lower at 0.34 volts causing imbalance.
Battery indicator/fuel gauge was not working, though the battery would charge and function normally at 19.8 volts.
Battery completely dead showing only 0.1 volts total, would not register on charger. All cell banks severely discharged.
Battery dead showing only 2 volts total, would not charge. Middle bank of cells completely failed showing zero volts while other banks showed around 3 volts each.
failure_reason: One bank of cells completely failed and replacement cells at matching voltage were not available

problem: Battery would not charge showing 12.5 volts total. Front bank of cells showed reverse polarity at minus 0.47 volts while other banks were around 3.3-3.4 volts.
The nailer was not working and the firing pin was bent like a banana. The tool had ramping up issues and hesitation when firing. The micro switch wasn't getting activated properly when ramping up.

The drill was very dirty and had been through harsh conditions. There was evidence of heat damage, burnt windings, and melting in the motor area. The tool had significant wear and damage from being 'hard put away wet'.
failure_reason: Motor windings were burnt and there was heat damage/melting in the motor area making the repair not viable long-term

problem: The nail gun was firing but nails were not moving up through the magazine, so no nails were actually coming out. The magazine spring had failed.
The tool had switch problems with intermittent speed control due to a dirty linear potentiometer and worn brass wiper contacts. Also had a missing ball spring for the belt clip retention mechanism.
54V battery pack had a squashed/broken contact pin and one completely dead cell reading 0 volts while other cells were at proper 3.46V.
failure_reason: Dead cell cannot be economically replaced due to complex disassembly required and high labor costs. 54V batteries have too much protection circuitry that shuts down permanently when cells fail.

problem: 54V battery pack with mangled/burnt connector that appeared to have previous failed repair attempts.
failure_reason: Connector too damaged to repair and replacement parts not available. Cannot use donor battery due to fault detection on circuit board.

problem: 20V brushed impact driver was running but armature was failing, causing arcing and eating away at the motor brushes, creating jagged worn surfaces on brush corners.
failure_reason: Armature and brush ring replacement would cost €90 plus labor, not economical compared to €150 for new tool with warranty.

problem: Tool was running smooth but not hammering strongly. Motor brushes were worn and nearly gone. O-rings on piston/striker needed replacement for proper hammer action.
54V grinder with burnt stator windings - some windings blackened/melted while others still fresh. Tool would initially start but shut down immediately when dead windings were energized.
failure_reason: Motor unit costs £280, more than entire tool price. Stator windings burnt out and not economically repairable.

problem: 54V grinder with broken solder joints on field windings - field was moving when it should be fixed in place. Multiple broken pins and burnt fields.
failure_reason: Multiple broken internal connections and burnt field windings. Pins broken inside housing beyond repair access.

problem: Power cord failure preventing the tool from starting.
18V brushless impact driver with switch problems - not going through speeds properly and belt clip not staying in due to missing ball spring.
20V impact driver from 2013 with severely worn plastic housing and failed LED. Switch still working and tool still functional but cosmetically damaged.
failure_reason: Not economical to repair 10-year-old tool - housing replacement costs €50 plus LED replacement on worn machine.

problem: Brushed impact driver with armature problems causing arcing and eating away at motor brush edges, creating sloped and damaged brush surfaces.
failure_reason: Motor replacement not economical on older brushed model when brushless versions are more powerful and cost only slightly more.

problem: Switch trigger not returning fully due to missing rubber seals that keep dirt out of the switch mechanism. Previous repair attempt was incomplete.

Major problems with rattling sound, motor moving back and forth inside housing, damaged gear teeth, previous repair done incorrectly without needle bearings causing extensive damage to armature and crank mechanism
failure_reason: Too much damage - would require €280 for armature, €30 for crank, plus service kit totaling over €400, more than half the price of the machine

problem: Nail gun making right noises but not firing nails, lost pressure in back chamber, no air to drive nails forward or drive the piston
Broken paper clamp on half sheet sander, clamp assembly damaged preventing proper paper attachment
Router not working at all, initially suspected speed control issue, found to be broken wire and switch jammed with sawdust causing poor contact
Customer thought speed control was not working - speed would not increase above low setting when tested
Brushes rusted and jammed inside motor holders, brush caps missing, springs and leads gone, motor wouldn't start due to corroded brushes stuck in holders
45 degree die grinder not working at all, blown noise suppression capacitor that was swollen and damaged, also had blown fuse
No power due to damaged power cord that breaks around the strain relief area from being swung and handed down from ladders and scaffolding
Light comes on but motor not running, brushes completely worn out with only spring touching the motor, motor needs replacement
failure_reason: Repair cost around 60-70 EUR for motor replacement on a tool worth 110-120 EUR new, parts ordered but repair pending cost approval

problem: No power, brushes worn out and snapped off, bearing worn
Motor not running consistently, brushes worn out and not making full contact with armature
Motor stops running, brushes worn out and losing contact halfway down, from same company as previous drill
Has power but not running, brushes worn causing sparking, armature showing signs of wear with oil leaks
Misfiring due to dirty spark plug contact point on cylinder head
Misfiring and not sinking nails properly, dirty internal components and seals
Broken firing pin in American model nail gun, requires expensive parts and conversion
failure_reason: Broken firing pin costs 150 EUR, plus conversion parts needed for American model, not economically viable

problem: Broken firing pin in second American model nail gun
failure_reason: Broken firing pin costs 150 EUR, plus this is an American model requiring conversion parts

problem: Australian model nail gun with broken firing pin, not worth repairing due to part costs and conversion requirements
failure_reason: Australian model requires expensive conversion parts and 150 EUR firing pin, manufacturer discourages conversions by inflating part prices

problem: Chuck jaws damaged and center screw head rounded off from drilling many holes in steel with large bits, cannot remove chuck normally
Motor not running, faulty trigger switch not providing continuity to motor or brake circuits
Keeps tripping circuit breaker due to multiple cuts in power cord with wires twisted together improperly
Started smoking during use, caused by loose battery connector that was arcing and overheating from drill vibration
Customer reported drill bit stuck in chuck and couldn't remove it, but actual issue was drill was in clutch mode preventing proper chuck operation

The drill was making juttering noises and not running properly. One of the three contacts feeding the brushless motor was burnt up and discolored, not getting proper contact. Only two lines were going into the field, causing the juttering. The field (stator) was also burnt out due to hard use by a steel fabricator.
The firing pin was broken/snapped at the tip and needed replacement. Customer said it just needs a new firing pin.
The drill was not taking or holding drill bits properly. The rubber cap at the end was worn out, causing the tool holder to sit in the up position all the time.
The grinder was trying to start but shutting down. The armature had been rubbing and moved loose, causing damage. Some laminates had delaminated.
failure_reason: Too much damage to the armature and possibly faulty hall effect sensor or weak magnets

problem: The saw switch was stuck in the on position and wouldn't turn off. The switch had failed with welded contacts, making it dangerous to use.
The hammer had burnt out motor components. The armature was completely burnt out after previous repairs costing €120.
failure_reason: Field for 110 volt version no longer available and repair costs too high (€180-200)

problem: The drill bit was jammed in the chuck and wouldn't release. The drill bit had mushroomed and the tool holder striker was damaged with a chip broken off one side.
failure_reason: Tool holder damaged beyond economical repair, parts too expensive for budget tool

problem: The power cord was completely burnt through and disconnected. Used for drilling holes for insulation bead pumping.
The firing pin was sticking out and wouldn't retract. Upon inspection, the pin had snapped and needed the whole top chamber assembly replaced.
failure_reason: Parts too expensive (€50-60 for chamber assembly) for budget tool, not economically viable

problem: The hammer was running very slowly due to a faulty speed controller. The soft start was too slow and speed control wasn't working properly.
The hammer function wasn't working. The drill was nearly 20 years old and the motor brushes were worn out.
The drill was sparking and didn't always turn on. Sometimes needed to be hit to start. The motor brushes were sticking in their holders due to corrosion.
The nail gun appeared to not be firing nails properly. The firing pin was stuck in the extended position after the tool fell about 7 feet and was accidentally put into maintenance mode.

The tool holder was broken - the pin holding the tool holder onto the shaft had failed. The tool holder itself was still functional but was detached from the shaft due to the broken hardened steel pin.

One bearing had seized and was spinning the outside of the bearing around inside the housing instead of the housing holding it. The bearing was jammed up and the housing was damaged from the bearing spinning inside it. Factory damage to the metal shield on the bearing likely caused overheating.

The saw turns but won't run properly - making knocking/grinding sounds. Either the brake is coming on prematurely while trying to run, or there's a dead segment in the motor/controller causing it to skip every rotation and only get power from two segments instead of three.
failure_reason: The motor and controller are one piece costing €250, making the repair not worth the cost

problem: The chuck was not holding bits properly due to dirt and grit buildup in the chuck mechanism preventing proper operation of the ball bearings and sleeve that secure the bits.
Switch was going up and down through speeds intermittently due to dirt buildup and the potentiometer wiper becoming pressed down and weakened over time, causing poor contact with the potentiometer.

The tool keeps shutting down intermittently and won't always run. The spade connector on one of the motor brush leads had melted and burnt due to vibration in the hammering machine causing poor connection.
The tool turns but is not running - appears to be a faulty controller or switch issue preventing proper operation.
failure_reason: Controller/switch unit is not serviceable and costs as much as the machine itself, making repair not economical

problem: Power cord was broken all over the place, motor brushes were completely worn out with nothing left, armature was badly worn causing sparking, and brake was locked on. The saw had seen very heavy rough use.

The hedge trimmer was completely non-functional - not doing anything when powered on. Tool was heavily contaminated with resin or similar substance. Issue appeared to be with the switch or controller system.
failure_reason: Controller had corrosion and the replacement controller unit costs over €100 while the tool itself costs about €170, making repair not economical

problem: Machine has a power cord leak, making rattling noises indicating bearing problems, and the tool holder is not holding the chisel properly. The chuck fell out during testing. Speed control issues were also present.
Sander had starting problems due to motor brushes worn at an angle and not making proper contact with the armature, causing arcing instead of proper electrical flow.
Had a broken bit jammed inside the tool holder that couldn't be removed normally. The bit had snapped off at the end and was stuck in the chuck mechanism.
Router had a blown segment on the armature causing clicking sounds and sparking. Also had a broken earth pin on the plug.
failure_reason: Customer declined repair due to high cost of armature replacement (€200-230)

problem: Second router was not running and had severe flashing from one side, then stopped completely. Found to have worn motor brushes causing arcing.
Saw had a broken spring in the blade guard mechanism causing the guard to not retract properly, leaving the blade exposed. Customer also wanted a new blade installed.
Grinder stopped working due to completely worn out motor brushes. The brush springs had popped and there was debris stuck in the brush holders.
Grinder had worn motor brushes with safety springs that stopped the machine, bad bearings, damaged power cord, and excessive dust buildup on the fan causing it to rub against the air deflector.
Sander had dust extraction problems due to a missing friction ring seal that allows proper suction. The old seal had burnt and broken, wrapping around the base mechanism.

Cordless grinder was making bad noises and barely working due to a failed bearing causing the armature to rub against the stator. The bearing race had dropped out and the grinder was full of metal debris.
Bit stuck in the tool holder. Someone had previously attempted to remove it and reassembled it incorrectly, causing the ball to get dented and jammed.
Motor not turning due to the fan melting and sticking to the plastic gearbox housing, creating a bond that prevented rotation.
Faulty rocker switch causing intermittent operation. Dust contamination inside the switch preventing proper contact.
Not firing nails, making clicking sound. Driver pin was worn out with flat spots preventing engagement with flywheel. Also had oil contamination affecting friction.
Bearing failure causing the tool to seize up and melt the plastic housing around the bearing.
Broken firing pin preventing the gun from shooting nails properly. Pin was bent and broken at the top.
Motor producing sparks and running hot. Armature failed with discolored commutator bars and excessive sparking from all brushes.
failure_reason: Repair cost too high - would exceed half the price of a new tool

problem: Making clicking sounds instead of firing. Likely another failed driver axis (third repair on this gun). Gun has fired 43,000 nails.
failure_reason: Customer did not approve expensive repair - cost would exceed savings from using the tool

problem: Motor struggling to run, burning smell, worn brushes, and broken blade clamp mechanism. Tool was completely packed with compacted sawdust mixed with grease.
Motor trying to run but jamming intermittently. A small steel ball was found loose in the gearbox causing the jam and minor tooth damage.

Customer says the hammer is not hammering. The motor sounds good and runs fine, but it's not generating impact/hammering action. The striker was too loose and flopping around, indicating worn O-rings and dried up grease in the hammer mechanism.

54V cordless grinder not starting consistently. Sometimes starts when you rotate it manually. The armature shaft is rusted and there appears to be issues with the hall effect sensors or controller not picking up rotor position, creating dead spots that prevent starting.
failure_reason: Cannot fix because DeWalt does not sell replacement parts separately - would need to replace entire motor assembly which costs nearly as much as a new machine

problem: Brand new planer totally jammed with spindle unthreaded and pinned against the cover. The pulley spindle had come loose from the drum shaft, preventing operation. Shows evidence of previous use with sawdust in box.
Vacuum works fine but when using the vibration feature to clean filters, a big plume of dust comes out the back when switched on again. This defeats the purpose of dust-free operation inside houses.
Power cord broken internally. The cable breaks just behind the strain relief grommet where the cord bends the most during use, causing fatigue failure.
Customer said it might need bearings, but the actual problem was a completely perished and broken drive belt that was 24 years old. The belt was completely clogged and had snapped.

Customer said it would not switch on and had no power whatsoever. The actual problem was that the compressor was already at maximum pressure from the last use, so the switch would not activate until the tank was emptied.
1000 Newton meter 1/2 inch drive impact wrench from 2016 was sputtering and sparking, with motor brushes burnt up due to failed or heated springs.
Small compact magnetic drill where the magnet worked and motor ran fine, but it wouldn't stay on. The solenoid inside the switch wasn't activating so it wasn't getting power to keep switched on.
Saw had fallen off a roof and broken the guard at the top. The damaged guard was causing cutting problems - it wouldn't push back properly or would get jammed halfway down during cuts.

18V cordless brushless trimmer would run for 10-20 minutes then shut down and not switch on again. After sitting for days it would work again temporarily. The problem was overheating due to completely clogged air intake vents blocking airflow to the motor.
Expensive drywall sander (600-700 Euro) was not switching on at all. The switch was giving trouble and eventually failed completely due to drywall dust contamination inside the switch mechanism.
Corded hedge trimmer from 2005 had its power cord cut when user got too close to the cable while operating. About 3 feet of cable needed to be removed and reconnected.
2016 brushed SDS drill was jammed with motor struggling to run. Two permanent magnets in the field had come loose and flipped around, jamming up the armature and causing it to rub against the field.
2023 cordless grinder had battery connection issues due to bent battery contacts not making proper contact. Also had a lock button that was packed with debris preventing it from functioning properly.
2017 brushed grinder was completely non-functional - not starting at all. Diagnosis revealed controller failure, which combined with the age and brush motor design made repair uneconomical.
failure_reason: Controller replacement cost too high relative to machine value, not worth fixing

problem: Grinder was starting and stopping intermittently and making abnormal noise. Multiple bearings had failed - the main bearing in the head and a 688 bearing, causing rough operation and noise. Also had corroded battery contacts.
The grinder was making a bad noise and smelling bad. Bearing failure was discovered with bearing seal holding it together barely.
Tool was running but starting to sound rough and spluttering. Spring tension was insufficient on motor brush causing poor contact.
Dead, no indicator lights, no function. Corroded and burnt contact on control board that took out the controller.
failure_reason: Control board replacement would cost 95-100 EUR making repair uneconomical compared to 145 EUR new price

problem: Motor brushes were worn, burnt and melted into the holder. Brush ring had melted from overheating.
Tool completely dead, light comes on but motor doesn't run. Controller PCB board failure with hot spots showing current not getting past failed components.
failure_reason: Motor unit replacement would cost 340 EUR plus labor totaling around 500 EUR, not economical compared to 800-850 EUR new price

problem: No gas firing, making motor sounds and spark but not igniting. Suspected out of date gas causing improper air/gas mixture for ignition.
failure_reason: Repair suspended pending customer return with more information about gas cartridge status

problem: Tool doing nothing, crackling sounds from switch. Switch failure and worn bearings causing rough operation.
Tool not functioning, motor brush melted onto holder with corrosion on field windings.
Motor brushes completely worn down to nothing, spring had popped off, armature worn from brushes only making partial contact.
Tool completely dead, motor brushes worn all the way down to spring which was half eaten. Severe armature damage from running brushes too long.

The grinder had a big vibration and was unbalanced. The lock pin had fallen down into the motor and gear, causing rubbing against the nut. The top nut holding the gear was worn away and the hole was too big to hold a new pin.
The grinder would not run due to a faulty power cord and plug. Someone had welded the plug together and there was a blown fuse.
The machine would stop working intermittently due to dirt, grit, and corrosion building up in the brush holders, preventing the brushes from making proper contact with the armature.
The grinder was missing its head and had screws that were too long for proper assembly.
The grinder had a clacking sound, three missing bolts from the head, rough feeling operation, faulty power cord with makeshift steel rod instead of fuse, and a failed bearing in the gear housing.
failure_reason: Not worth fixing - repair costs would exceed 40 euros while the machine only costs 50-60 euros new

problem: A 25mm bit was stuck inside the tool holder, rusted and jammed up. The bit was improperly installed directly into the tool holder without proper adapter, causing the impact mechanism to bind up.
The grinder was running too slow and weak, with something rubbing inside. The gear head had packed up causing a gap so gears weren't meshing correctly. Also had a failed lock pin.
The 9-inch grinder was very sparky due to worn down motor brushes that had worn to almost nothing and were jammed in their holders. The machine was also heavily corroded from salt water exposure.
Drill would not work when plugged in, but would spark into life when the motor was given a slap. The brushes were worn out and no longer making contact with the armature due to wear.

Motor was running and hammering but losing power, getting weaker and weaker when drilling through concrete walls. The brushes were burnt, overheated and cracked so they couldn't move in the holders properly.
Nail gun was running and shooting sometimes but other times just clicking instead of firing. The axis inside was worn out and not getting enough downward force to press the driver onto the flywheel.
Drill was stuck in hammer mode and couldn't switch back to normal drill mode. The plastic gearbox had melted and jammed the hammer mechanism forward so it was always engaged.
Mixer drill was not working at all and the change lever was missing. The switch was dead and corroded, and the change lever mechanism was caked with dirt and not moving freely.

Push button switch jammed, then discovered field coil was shorted out internally, making contact with steel body causing overheating and burning the contacts. Switch was blown due to excessive current draw from shorted field.
failure_reason: Field coil completely burnt and shorted out, repair cost would exceed replacement cost

problem: Hammer stopped working - making motions but no hammering action. Grease had liquefied from overuse and leaked into motor. Broken steel washer in striker mechanism prevented proper hammer function.
failure_reason: Missing holder sleeve part needed to be ordered, repair incomplete

problem: Motor brushes worn out due to failed brush holder spring. One brush completely worn down to wire while other remained good. Bearing also failed in motor housing causing noise.
Losing oil from gearbox due to grease becoming liquefied from overuse and overheating, causing it to leak out through unsealed areas. Bearings also worn allowing grease to pass through seals.
Nail gun keeps jamming on 16 gauge brad nails and bending them. Pin has mushroomed from firing hardened steel nails into concrete, causing it to lose its square edge.
Machine sounds rough and smoking. Speed control feedback system failed due to broken tachometer disc that came off the armature shaft. Bearing also completely failed.
Bearing failure causing rough running and noise. This was the second bearing replacement on this unit.

No hammer function, covered in wrong type of black molly grease (too heavy), bearing failure, damaged housing from previous piston damage, old needle rollers jammed in piston head, top cap completely destroyed, worn motor brushes with angled wear pattern
One brush touching the armature while the other wasn't, brush holders not setting level with one tweaked to one side, damaged connector on brush holder
Power button working but no motor function, loose connector found disconnected, missing screws from previous repair attempts, missing rubber dampers causing excessive movement in motor assembly
failure_reason: Controller fault detected via thermal imaging, not worth replacing due to high cost

problem: Machine keeps shutting down after running for short periods, sparking visible from suppression filter area, overheated and burned suppression filter causing short circuit
Motor seized and not turning at all after cutting through wire rope, plastic oil pump ring melted and bound up in housing, plastic worm gear for oil feed damaged
Making nasty grinding sounds, two bad bearings causing noise and rough operation
Corded drill doing nothing, had a burnt connector that was burnt onto the side of the housing. The right angle connector on the brush holder was burnt but there was still enough left to connect to.
The control panel was smashed - somebody dropped something on it and broke the panel. The vacuum was working fine otherwise, just needed the control panel replaced.
Small sliding compound miter saw had a lot of lateral play on the motor section and play on the arms. The power cord also needed to be changed due to stripped connectors.

Compressor was starting up and running, taking on air and not leaking, but not increasing in pressure. The non-return valve was broken - the brass fitting had sheared off, allowing compressed air to flow back out of the tank.

Laser level was not working, had the same crack as a previous unit. Housing was melted down and spring looked shorted out and burnt. Initially appeared to be a battery contact problem with dirty/burnt contacts.
800W rotary hammer had no sound and wasn't working. The issue was a 3 amp fuse in an 800W machine, which was insufficient - needed a 13 amp fuse.

18V cordless circular saw wasn't working. Had melted connectors and burn marks, indicating it had been overworked and overheated. The controller was blown with resin burned out and melted plastic connectors.
Making a horrible vibrating sound, something not right inside the motor. Housing melted where it sits on steel insert, bearing worn out, fan had a section eaten away causing vibration.
Brush holder melted and pressed over to one side, wouldn't close right, missing screws. Machine was overworked causing brushes to heat up and melt the plastic brush holder.
Stator was burnt out on the inside, very much down on power due to burnt out stator.
Switch not wired correctly, swollen capacitor that had gone bad. Machine wouldn't work properly.
Sounded rough, bearings were gone causing rough operation. Also had broken plastic piece in handle causing rattle.
Hand sticking out, nail feed jammed with rust from sitting idle for a long time. Return bands were snapped and firing pin was bent up causing snagging.

Gun goes through the motions and makes the firing sound but doesn't actually fire nails. Trigger assembly has wear and O-rings are worn, causing firing pin to stay under pressure and not fully retract.
failure_reason: Cannot obtain spare parts for Senco tools in Ireland due to Brexit - market too small for suppliers

problem: A lot of vibration going back into handle, striker locked onto piston or seals gone. Striker not moving so force not getting through to chisel. Impact bolt jammed due to dirt and gunk, O-ring seated incorrectly with grit and dirt.
Gun not starting when plunged down due to probe set too far back, not making enough travel to engage switch. Rust damage on switch and bump mode switch jammed up and dirty.
Fires one shot then just clicks. Springs broken in four pieces due to rust. Gun starts but only fires one nail then stops working.
Firing but not putting in nails. Missing nail guide/slider, metal slider, magazine lock, and spring that pushes nails up. Multiple components missing from magazine mechanism.
failure_reason: Multiple parts missing and need to be ordered - could take up to a month to arrive

problem: Not working, motor sounds terrible and bone dry. Reed strip jammed preventing pin from returning. One-way check valve not sealing properly so pan doesn't go back. Everything gummed up and dry.
Motor jammed and won't turn. Top bearing totally collapsed, motor brushes gone. Armature been rubbing and some plastic melted off fan from rubbing against field when it cooled down and stuck.
Tool was making grinding noise and rough operation. Bearings were failing with dirt, grit, water, and rust causing noise. Plaster and cement debris stuck to aluminum housing and corroded parts.
Drill was running but didn't have the same power at full speed and would stall under heavy load. The field coil was overheated and burnt, with black windings and melted plastic lining.
Switch was not making contact consistently, causing intermittent operation. The switch contacts were dirty and needed cleaning.

Tool was making rubbing noise and something was wrong internally. An 18 gauge brad nail had been sucked into the motor through the large vents and was rubbing against the fan, causing heating and melting.
Gas framing nailer brought in for routine service and cleaning. Tool was working and firing properly but needed preventive maintenance.
Handle was jammed and tool had stripped gears. Three planetary gears were completely destroyed with teeth broken off and scattered throughout the gearbox.

The tool would start working normally but then shut off while the motor kept running for a bit longer instead of stopping instantly with the electronic brake. This indicated a broken wire inside that prevented the electronic brake from engaging properly.
The drill had a cracked housing and broken battery clips, plus the motor had completely worn out brushes with one brush holder folded around inside the armature.
The drill was completely dead with worn out motor brushes. The brushes were missing and the brass strips for holding the brushes had folded around inside the armature, destroying the motor.
This cheap drill with a basic DC motor was dead due to completely worn out brushes. The brass brush holder was touching the armature and had bent to the wrong position.
Another drill with the same issue - motor brushes were completely gone and the brass brush holder was touching the armature, causing the motor to fail.
This 2014 drill had worn out brushes with the brass brush holder positioned on the wrong side and sitting in the wrong orientation after the brushes wore out.
This 2014 drill had completely worn out brushes in its universal motor, but the brushes were replaceable unlike the DC motors in other drills.
This 2016 drill had barely any power due to completely worn out motor brushes. The spring was bottoming out on the brass brush holder and the brushes were no longer making contact with the armature.
failure_reason: Motor replacement would cost €80 which is too expensive to be worth repairing this lower-end drill model

problem: This 2020 drill with metal gearbox had completely worn through brushes, but was otherwise in good condition and well-maintained.
The nail gun was firing but nails were not moving up from the magazine, so no nails were actually coming out. The magazine spring was gone.
Switch had intermittent speed issues due to dirty contacts and worn brass wiper losing pressure against the potentiometer. Also had a broken ball spring preventing the bit from staying in.
54V battery had a squashed pin causing broken contact and one completely dead cell reading 0 volts while others were at 3.46 volts.
failure_reason: Dead cell cannot be economically replaced and 54V batteries have too much protection that prevents successful boosting

problem: 54V battery was undercharged and had damaged/mangled connector that appeared to have been previously repaired.
failure_reason: Cannot get replacement connector parts and previous repair damage makes it uneconomical to fix

problem: 20V American model impact wrench was still working but had worn armature causing arcing and eating away at the brushes.
failure_reason: Armature replacement would cost about €90 which is not economical for a tool that can be bought new for €150

problem: Hammer was running smooth but not hammering strongly. Motor brushes were almost gone and O-rings on piston/striker needed replacement. Required full service including bearings, seals, and grease.
54V grinder had burnt out stator windings (some blackened/melted) and damaged bearing. Motor would initially start but shut down immediately.
failure_reason: Motor unit costs more than entire new tool (€280 vs €280 for complete tool) making repair uneconomical

problem: 54V grinder had broken field windings with pins broken inside the motor and damaged gearbox bearings with grease leakage.
failure_reason: Broken field pins cannot be accessed for repair and would require motor unit replacement which costs more than new tool

problem: Bench grinder had a faulty power cord that was intermittently losing connection.
18V brushless impact driver had switch problem with dirty contacts and missing ball spring for bit retention.
20V American model from 2013 had worn plastic housing and failed LED, but switch and mechanics still functioned.
failure_reason: 10-year-old machine with cosmetic housing damage not worth €50 repair cost

problem: Brushed impact wrench had worn armature causing arcing and brush damage, with failed LED.
failure_reason: Motor replacement not economical on older brushed model when brushless alternatives available

problem: Switch was not returning fully due to missing rubber seals that keep dirt out of the trigger mechanism.

The machine had multiple issues including a bad oil leak, worn armature gear teeth, cracked housing, failed bearings and seals, worn and damaged striker bolt with dents in the middle, broken tool holder with chips and damage, broken switch that was likely the reason it stopped working, missing steel balls and other small parts.
The sander was not running, seems to be trying but doing nothing. Motor appeared to be blocked from turning, likely due to a seized bearing stopping motor rotation.
The jigsaw was not holding the blade properly. The blade would slide out under load due to worn blade holder with damaged slots that allowed the blade to pull out during cutting.
Impact driver not holding bits properly due to broken spring mechanism inside the chuck that no longer locks bits in place.
