Double charger had one side working and one side not working. The non-working side had damaged yellow contacts that were mangled with buildup, preventing proper charging function.
Impact wrench was getting lights but not doing anything. Controller board had failed with visible hot spots and damage, making sizzling sounds when triggered.
failure_reason: Controller replacement would cost around €300, more than the machine is worth

problem: Drill was not running and had been opened previously with wrong screws installed in wrong places. Motor appeared jammed and had various internal issues.
failure_reason: Multiple component failures including motor, controller, and switch problems - cost nearly as much as a new machine

problem: Drill had no power, no lights coming on. Controller/electronic module had failed, likely due to water damage or moisture getting into the switch assembly.
Angle grinder not turning on and had been sitting unused for a long time. Stator was burnt out with coil damage, magnet came loose and was rubbing on rotor causing overheating and eventual failure.
failure_reason: Controller replacement costs €150, not economically viable to repair

problem: Drill was making straining/fighting sounds, sometimes starting and stopping, sometimes wouldn't drive forward but would go in reverse. Issue was in the gearbox where the clutch mechanism and lock pins were gummed up with hardened grease.
Chuck was jammed with a drill bit stuck in it, making it impossible to remove the bit or use the chuck properly. The chuck jaws were rounded and not aligning correctly, plus there was rust present.

Tool keeps shutting down during use - runs fine but stops dead every 10 seconds during operation. Also has a worn armature that has rubbed through and is hitting the field magnets, causing discoloration in the field windings.
failure_reason: Too expensive to repair properly - would need new armature (~80) and field (~30) plus labor, totaling about 150 on a machine worth around that much. Only received temporary fix by adjusting field position.

problem: Motor completely failed with armature segments lifted and burnt at the back. 2012 machine that has seen extensive use over 12 years.
failure_reason: Not worth repairing - armature costs 25-30 plus brushes, totaling about 45-50 to fix, but machine only worth 70-90. Past halfway mark for repair costs on a 12-year-old well-used machine.

problem: Tool stopped working completely - no power at all. Issue was caused by a loose wire connection at the switch terminal.
Motor brushes melted and not making contact. Brush holder was melted from heavy use and abuse. Machine had seen considerable wear.
Power cord damaged and brushes were stuck/corroded in their holders causing arcing and spluttering. Machine was covered in grinder dust and corrosion from sitting in damp conditions.
36 volt SDS hammer mode not working - piston was broken and o-ring failed. Grease had gone hard and congealed, causing the piston to run dry and break.

24v nickel metal hydride battery not holding charge - charges too quickly (5-10 minutes) and only provides 2-3 holes of use. Battery has developed memory from sitting unused and not being properly maintained.
Motor burnt out with both brush holders melted, armature segments discolored and burnt. Machine had a burnt motor smell and was clearly overworked until failure.
Chuck needs replacement - while still functional, it has seen better days and customer wants it changed. Chuck was very tight and required gearbox disassembly to remove.
Tool not making any sound, motor not running at all. Light comes on but no motor activity whatsoever. 10 years old DC motor machine from 2013.
failure_reason: Not economically viable to repair - switch costs €100 and motor would likely fail soon after, better to replace with new brushless model

problem: Bearings failed and melted the plastic housing. Housing plastic melted and fused together, making it difficult to open. Tool from 2000, 23 years old.
Not hammering and jammed up mechanism. Motor was running but hammer mechanism was disengaged and jammed due to failed spring. Grease had leaked out and motor was full of grease.
Voltage too low at 1.2V, cells unbalanced, water damage and corrosion present.
failure_reason: Dead cells and water damage, not worth fixing due to safety concerns and cost

problem: Voltage at 8V, water damage, corrosion on contacts, dead cells present.
failure_reason: Dead cells and corrosion, not economically viable to repair

problem: Voltage at 4V, water damage and corrosion, dead cells present.
failure_reason: Dead cells and water damage, not worth fixing

problem: Two cells completely dead at 0V while other cells at 4.8V, fully charged except for failed cells.
failure_reason: Dead cells that have shorted out, would require cell replacement which is not cost effective

problem: Voltage at 16.3V, just below charging threshold, charger won't recognize it.
failure_reason: Two dead cells present, spiking would be dangerous and ineffective

problem: Too low voltage, water damage and corrosion, first two cells dead at 3.5V.
failure_reason: Dead cells and water damage, not cost effective to repair

problem: Customer reported that bits were not staying in the drill and would pull out during use.
Totally dead, no power, burnt circuit board visible inside.
failure_reason: Burnt circuit board, not worth fixing due to cost

problem: Switch not working, worn out brushes that melted into the body, armature burnt with high resistance causing overheating.
failure_reason: Multiple expensive components needed replacement, not economically viable - would cost 70-80 compared to 130 for new tool

problem: Burnt out motor, armature heavily worn and rounded at edges, windings and commutator segments burnt out and shorted.
failure_reason: Extensive motor damage requiring multiple expensive parts, not economically viable to repair

problem: 3 amp battery with voltage at 13V, first two cells dead.
failure_reason: Dead cells in small capacity battery, not worth fixing

problem: Voltage too low, two dead cells present.
failure_reason: Dead cells, not cost effective to repair

problem: One dead cell, voltage too low for charging.
failure_reason: Dead cell, not worth fixing

problem: Switch totally worn out and losing contact, still running but switch failing.
failure_reason: Switch costs €70 while complete tool can be bought for €90-100, not economically viable

problem: Motor was jammed and wouldn't turn. Investigation revealed that one or two fins had broken off the cast aluminum fan, causing debris to jam the motor. The broken fan pieces prevented the armature from spinning despite power reaching the motor.

The drill was working but had no hammer action. The impact bolt was stuck solid due to rust and dirt/grit buildup from drilling in muddy or dirty conditions. Water and debris had gotten into the tool holder area and caused the impact bolt to seize up.

The sander was completely non-functional - not turning on at all. Upon inspection, a component on the power board had blown apart completely, likely along with potential damage to the bridge rectifier. The machine was also extremely dusty indicating poor maintenance.
failure_reason: Customer contact information not available and expensive repair part would be ordered without guarantee of customer return

problem: The chuck was completely seized and stuck solid. The chuck mechanism had failed internally with the sleeve spinning freely, making it impossible to open or close the chuck to change bits. The ratcheting mechanism inside was not working properly.
The drill had a faulty trigger switch that would work partially but would stop working when pulled to full trigger position. The switch contacts were failing under full load conditions.

18V battery pack showing 16.5 volts but not charging. Two cells in the back of the pack were reading only 6 volts total (dead cells) while the other cells were at normal voltage around 4V each. Dead cells prevent proper charging.
failure_reason: Dead cells cannot be repaired and replacement would be unsafe due to mixing good and bad cells

problem: Battery pack with severe corrosion on both the circuit board and cells. Multiple dead cells detected. Pack was showing 14.7 volts overall but had dead cells in the back section.
failure_reason: Severe corrosion damage and multiple dead cells make repair unsafe and not cost effective

problem: Newer style battery pack with water damage throughout. Case was still wet inside even after sitting for over a week. Water had penetrated behind the plastic casing. Case was also physically damaged/smashed.
failure_reason: Severe water damage and no replacement case available for this newer model

problem: Sander was making clicking noise and appeared jammed - the base would not turn when switched on. A small nylon brake belt had come off its position and gotten caught in the impeller fan underneath, jamming the entire mechanism.
Battery showing no bars, not charging, voltage reading 15.3-15.4 volts which is too low. One bank of cells completely dead while other banks were well balanced at 3.65 volts each.
Broken mounting bracket on the red beam laser level. The bracket was damaged and needed replacement.
Circular saw with fully charged battery not working. Brushes were worn down very far and needed replacement.
Old brushed impact wrench doesn't have the same power and has a burning smell. Brushes were falling apart and crumbling, well beyond their useful life.
Angle grinder was noisy and stiff. The bearing was faulty and could be removed by hand, indicating it was completely worn out.

Battery only showing 4.44-4.5 volts instead of 17-20 volts expected for 18V battery. Individual cell banks were showing 0.92-0.94 volts which is extremely low. Jump starting and circuit board reset failed.
Battery had physical damage from a fall, damaged casing and terminals. Battery was working but connection issues due to damaged terminals and casing.

Battery showing no LED lights in tool, won't charge, clicking sound from charger but not actually charging. Voltage around 9 volts and dropping. Individual cell banks very low at 1.71-1.75 volts but well balanced.

Battery showing no bars, not charging, not lighting LED in drill, reading 12.73V. Spot weld failure caused complete disconnection of nickel strip, creating voltage imbalance between cells (3.41V vs 0.5V). One cell was damaged beyond recovery.

The switch activator is coming out and the switch lever is not staying in position properly. Part of the plastic mechanism that holds the activator down has broken off, making the tool dangerous to operate as it could activate unexpectedly.
The drill keeps dropping the drill bit, which is caused by a rough and uneven chuck cover that is not properly holding the ball mechanism in place to secure the bit in the chuck.

Battery only charges to two bars and powers 18V machines but provides no power when used in Flexvolt tools. Caused by overheat/overload from being used on a faulty Flexvolt machine, resulting in broken connections due to pressure and popping.

Battery only charges to two bars and powers 18V machines but provides no power when used in Flexvolt tools. Caused by overheat/overload from being used to jump start a smaller battery, resulting in broken connections due to pressure and popping.
Tool has power (lights are on) but the motor does not run despite being only 5 months old. Issue was identified as a problem with the power cord near the plug end.

Vacuum cleaner does not work at all when a fully charged battery is installed and switch is activated. Circuit board is fried and switch is also burnt out, making it extensively damaged with only the motor remaining functional.

Battery showing only 9.6 volts, very low voltage. Will not work in power drill, won't turn on LED, and charger shows fully charged light immediately. Two cells in one bank were completely dead with essentially no voltage.
Motor has expired and burned out. Previous attempt to replace brushes did not fix the issue.
Switch activator problem - the switch activator is coming out and the owner had to cable tie it closed which is dangerous. A plastic bit that holds the switch down is broken or missing.
Two defective cells showing less than half a volt while other cells show 3.84 volts, causing battery imbalance and poor performance.
Bit broken off in the chuck that could not be removed despite multiple attempts.
Saw not working properly, owner tried replacing brushes and lost one of the caps in the process. Controller identified as the likely problem.
Noisy and stiff operation due to failed bearing that could be removed by bare hands, indicating severe wear.

Not running properly, sounds like soft start but has no soft start feature. Brush holder is overheated and melted, brush caps closed permanently, brushes not making good contact due to melted brush holders not allowing proper sliding.
